title: My Hearing Aids Do Not Help Me at All
chief_complaint: My hearing aids are of no benefit and often make things worse in noisy listening environments. It is as if the hearing aids mix noise with the voices I am trying to hear.

problem_summary.onset: Slow deterioration over the past 5 years.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Infrequent 'buzzing noise' (tinnitus); difficulty hearing in noise; agitation regarding TV volume.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Affecting work as an accountant (meetings, phone calls) and home life (grandchildren, TV volume).
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Highly motivated; self-referred for hearing aids initially.

history.present_illness: Patient on a 4-week trial of bilateral BTE hearing aids. Reports benefit in quiet but significant difficulty in noise, often removing aids to hear better.
history.otologic_history: No history of vertigo, noise exposure, or family history of hearing loss.
history.medical_psych_history: Generally healthy; takes OTC medication for hay fever.
history.prior_management: Currently in week 3 of a 4-week hearing aid trial (NAL-NL2 targets met).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical mild-to-moderate sensorineural hearing loss, gradually sloping.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild loss in ability to receive speech (SRT). Word recognition good in quiet with no significant rollover.

tests.name: Tympanometry & Reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function (Type A tympanograms) but absent acoustic reflexes.

numeric_results.Acoustic_Reflexes: Absent ipsilateral and contralateral at 500-4000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise (SPIN)
tests.key_findings: Performance improved with HAs in quiet, but significantly degraded with HAs in noise compared to unaided.

tests.name: Hearing Aid Verification
tests.key_findings: Hearing aids performing within manufacturer specifications. Real-ear insertion gain (REIG) met NAL-NL2 targets.

history.present_illness: Referral for site-of-lesion assessment due to absent ARTs and poor aided performance in noise.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (OAEs)
tests.key_findings: TEOAEs and DPOAEs present with abnormally large amplitudes, suggesting disinhibition of outer hair cell activity.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Significantly degraded waveform morphology. No repeatable Wave I. No prominent cochlear microphonic.

tests.name: CAPD Battery
tests.key_findings: Performed poorly on 5 out of 6 behavioral tests. Severe temporal processing deficits.

numeric_results.RGDT: Unable to detect gaps up to 40 msec

tests.name: Auditory Late Latency Response (ALLR)
tests.key_findings: Degraded waveform morphology and poor repeatability bilaterally. Waves N1 and P1 identified at latencies and amplitudes within normal limits.

tests.name: Memory Screening
tests.key_findings: Passed screening assessment of short-term and working memory (TAPS-R subtests).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a mild-to-moderate sensorineural hearing loss on the audiogram but exhibits a profile consistent with Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD). Key indicators include absent acoustic reflexes, present and robust OAEs, and absent/degraded ABR waveforms. Functionally, this results in severe difficulty understanding speech in noise and temporal processing deficits, explaining why amplification exacerbates the signal-to-noise problem.
counseling_points: Your hearing difficulty is not just about volume (sensitivity) but about how the nerve sends timing information to the brain (synchrony). This is called Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD).
This condition explains why hearing aids help in quiet (making sounds louder) but hurt in noise (amplifying the 'blur' or distortion).
We recommend medical clearance with an otologist and neurologist.
For management, visual communication strategies are crucial. You may continue using hearing aids in quiet if helpful, but removing them in noise is a valid strategy.
Cochlear implants are a potential treatment option to consider if difficulties persist, as they can bypass the dyssynchronous part of the ear.
